1.title: Regulatory Framework
1.coreNarrative: Every regulator exists because someone got burned. The entire regulatory structure is a monument to past failures.

stories.title: The Crash That Created the SEC
stories.summary: Between 1929-1932, the market lost 89% of its value. $30 billion in market value vanished in two days. The public discovered rampant manipulation, insider trading, and fraudulent securities.
stories.memorableDetail: Joseph Kennedy, known for his own market manipulation, was appointed first SEC chairman. FDR's logic: 'Set a thief to catch a thief.'
stories.usageNote: Perfect for explaining why disclosure requirements exist

stories.title: NASD + NYSE Regulation = FINRA
stories.summary: The NASD (National Association of Securities Dealers) merged with NYSE's regulatory arm to create FINRA, consolidating broker-dealer oversight.
stories.memorableDetail: The merger happened partly because having two separate regulators created gaps that firms could exploit.
stories.usageNote: Explains why FINRA exists as unified SRO

stories.title: Bernie Madoff's $65 Billion Fraud
stories.summary: The largest Ponzi scheme in history ran for decades despite multiple SEC investigations. Madoff was a former NASDAQ chairman.
stories.memorableDetail: Harry Markopolos warned the SEC repeatedly for 9 years. His report was titled 'The World's Largest Hedge Fund is a Fraud.'
stories.usageNote: Why independent verification and custody rules matter

stories.title: Glass-Steagall: Banks vs. Brokers
stories.summary: Separated commercial banking from investment banking after banks were caught pushing worthless securities on depositors.
stories.memorableDetail: National City Bank (now Citibank) was caught having salesmen push bad bonds to depositors while executives secretly sold their own holdings.
stories.usageNote: Historical context for understanding financial industry structure

2.title: Types of Securities
2.coreNarrative: Securities are just formalized promises. Understanding what's being promised—and what can go wrong—is the key.

stories.title: The South Sea Bubble
stories.summary: The South Sea Company promised monopoly trading rights with South America. Stock soared 800% then collapsed. Isaac Newton lost £20,000 (millions today).
stories.memorableDetail: Newton famously said: 'I can calculate the motion of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people.'
stories.usageNote: Timeless lesson about speculation vs. investment

stories.title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room
stories.summary: Energy giant collapsed due to massive accounting fraud. $74 billion in shareholder value evaporated. Led to Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
stories.memorableDetail: Enron was named 'America's Most Innovative Company' by Fortune for 6 consecutive years—while committing fraud.
stories.usageNote: Why financial disclosure and auditor rules exist

stories.title: The First Government Bond
stories.summary: England issued the first government bond (a 'tontine') to fund war against France. The concept: government borrows from citizens, pays interest.
stories.memorableDetail: The Bank of England was literally created to manage this debt. It's still paying some of these perpetual bonds.
stories.usageNote: Origin story for government securities

stories.title: Michael Milken and the Junk Bond Revolution
stories.summary: Milken pioneered high-yield 'junk' bonds at Drexel Burnham Lambert, enabling hostile takeovers and LBOs. Made $550 million in one year.
stories.memorableDetail: Milken was later convicted of securities fraud, banned from the industry, and fined $600 million. He's now a billionaire philanthropist.
stories.usageNote: Illustrates bond credit spectrum and regulatory consequences

stories.title: Tulip Mania
stories.summary: Dutch tulip bulb prices rose to 10x annual salary of skilled craftsman before collapsing. Often cited as first recorded speculative bubble.
stories.memorableDetail: At peak, futures contracts on tulips traded more than the bulbs themselves—an early form of derivatives.
stories.usageNote: Ancient example of speculation, useful for derivatives discussion

3.title: Customer Accounts
3.coreNarrative: Account rules exist to protect customers from firms—and sometimes from themselves.

stories.title: Allen Stanford's $7 Billion CD Fraud
stories.summary: Stanford Financial sold CDs promising impossibly high returns from an Antigua bank. $7 billion lost. Stanford got 110 years.
stories.memorableDetail: Stanford was knighted by Antigua. He sponsored cricket tournaments. The veneer of legitimacy fooled even sophisticated investors.
stories.usageNote: Why KYC and account verification matter

stories.title: Buying on Margin in 1929
stories.summary: Investors could buy stocks with just 10% down. When prices fell, margin calls cascaded. Forced selling accelerated the crash.
stories.memorableDetail: Regulation T now requires 50% initial margin—directly because of 1929's 10% margin disaster.
stories.usageNote: Origin of margin requirements

stories.title: The Churning Scandals
stories.summary: Major brokerages were caught 'churning'—excessive trading to generate commissions regardless of client benefit.
stories.memorableDetail: One Prudential broker made 300 trades in a widow's account in one year, generating $50,000 in commissions on a $250,000 account.
stories.usageNote: Why trading suitability rules exist

4.title: Suitability & Recommendations
4.coreNarrative: Suitability rules exist because brokers kept selling grandma high-risk investments.

stories.title: Dot-Com Bubble Retail Carnage
stories.summary: Retail investors poured savings into profitless tech stocks. Many quit jobs to day trade. The NASDAQ fell 78% from peak.
stories.memorableDetail: Pets.com IPO'd at $11, spent $1.2 million on a Super Bowl ad, and was bankrupt 9 months later. Stock ended at $0.19.
stories.usageNote: Why matching investments to client profiles matters

stories.title: Auction Rate Securities Freeze
stories.summary: Banks sold auction-rate securities as 'cash equivalents.' When auctions failed in 2008, $330 billion became illiquid overnight.
stories.memorableDetail: UBS, Citi, and others paid billions in settlements for selling these as 'safe' to customers who needed liquidity.
stories.usageNote: Suitability means understanding product risks, not just returns

stories.title: Variable Annuity Sales Scandals
stories.summary: Brokers pushed complex, high-commission variable annuities to elderly clients who didn't need them or understand them.
stories.memorableDetail: FINRA found cases of 85-year-olds sold 15-year surrender-period annuities. The math didn't work.
stories.usageNote: Why age and time horizon matter for suitability

5.title: Municipal & Government Securities
5.coreNarrative: Government debt seems safe—until it isn't. Cities and countries default too.

stories.title: Detroit's $18 Billion Bankruptcy
stories.summary: Largest municipal bankruptcy in US history. General obligation bondholders recovered 74 cents on the dollar.
stories.memorableDetail: Detroit had been issuing bonds for decades with declining tax base. The pension obligations alone were $3.5 billion underfunded.
stories.usageNote: Even GO bonds backed by 'full faith and credit' can default

stories.title: Orange County's Derivatives Disaster
stories.summary: County treasurer Robert Citron bet $7.5 billion of public funds on interest rate derivatives. Lost $1.7 billion. County declared bankruptcy.
stories.memorableDetail: Citron had no formal finance training. He used astrology and psychics for investment decisions. He still got re-elected twice.
stories.usageNote: Why municipal oversight matters

stories.title: Puerto Rico's $74 Billion Default
stories.summary: Puerto Rico defaulted on municipal bonds, the largest ever. Triple tax-exempt status had attracted mainland investors for decades.
stories.memorableDetail: The bonds were sold to mainland retirees seeking tax-free income. Many held concentrated positions and lost substantial savings.
stories.usageNote: Tax benefits don't eliminate credit risk

stories.title: Hamilton's Revolutionary Debt Deal
stories.summary: Alexander Hamilton convinced federal government to assume all state Revolutionary War debts, establishing US credit and creating the first Treasury bonds.
stories.memorableDetail: The deal included moving the capital to Washington DC—a compromise with Southern states who had less debt. The musical skipped some details.
stories.usageNote: Origin of US Treasury securities

6.title: Investment Companies
6.coreNarrative: Mutual funds democratized investing—but created new ways to exploit investors.

stories.title: John Bogle Invents the Index Fund
stories.summary: Bogle launched the first retail index fund at Vanguard. Wall Street called it 'Bogle's Folly.' It now manages trillions.
stories.memorableDetail: The first index fund raised only $11 million vs. $150 million target. Competitors mocked it as 'un-American.' Bogle never took Vanguard public, keeping it owned by fund shareholders.
stories.usageNote: Origin of passive investing revolution

stories.title: The Mutual Fund Timing Scandal
stories.summary: Major fund companies allowed hedge funds to 'market time'—rapidly trade fund shares at stale prices, extracting billions from regular shareholders.
stories.memorableDetail: Putnam, Janus, Strong, and others were implicated. Strong's founder was banned for life. Industry paid $3.1 billion in settlements.
stories.usageNote: Why NAV rules and trading restrictions exist

stories.title: The Birth of ETFs
stories.summary: The SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY) launched as first US ETF. Combined mutual fund diversification with stock-like trading.
stories.memorableDetail: SPY is now the most traded security in the world. Average daily volume exceeds $30 billion.
stories.usageNote: ETF origin and structure

stories.title: Reserve Primary Fund Breaks the Buck
stories.summary: First money market fund since 1994 to 'break the buck'—NAV fell below $1 due to Lehman Brothers exposure. Triggered industry-wide panic.
stories.memorableDetail: The fund held $785 million in Lehman paper. When Lehman failed, NAV dropped to $0.97. The government created emergency guarantees to prevent mass redemptions.
stories.usageNote: Money market funds aren't risk-free

7.title: Trading Markets
7.coreNarrative: Markets have evolved from trading under a buttonwood tree to algorithms executing in microseconds.

stories.title: The Buttonwood Agreement
stories.summary: 24 brokers signed an agreement under a buttonwood tree on Wall Street, agreeing to trade only with each other and charge fixed commissions. Birth of NYSE.
stories.memorableDetail: The tree stood at 68 Wall Street until 1865. The original agreement was essentially a price-fixing cartel—now illegal.
stories.usageNote: NYSE origin story

stories.title: The Flash Crash
stories.summary: Dow Jones dropped 1,000 points (9%) in minutes, then recovered. Caused by algorithmic trading cascade. Some stocks traded at $0.01, others at $100,000.
stories.memorableDetail: Accenture traded at $0.01. Sotheby's at $99,999.99. P&G dropped 37% in minutes. New circuit breaker rules followed.
stories.usageNote: Why trading halts and circuit breakers exist

stories.title: Knight Capital's $440 Million Software Glitch
stories.summary: A software deployment error caused Knight Capital to execute $7 billion in errant trades in 45 minutes. Lost $440 million. Company sold within a week.
stories.memorableDetail: The bug activated old test code that was supposed to have been deleted. 45 minutes of chaos ended a 17-year-old firm.
stories.usageNote: Operational risk in modern markets

stories.title: NASDAQ: The Electronic Exchange
stories.summary: First electronic stock exchange, allowing dealers to post quotes on computer screens instead of shouting on a floor.
stories.memorableDetail: NASDAQ started as 'National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations.' Apple, Microsoft, Amazon—all listed there, not NYSE.
stories.usageNote: Dealer vs. auction market structure

stories.title: The NASDAQ Odd-Eighth Scandal
stories.summary: Researchers discovered NASDAQ dealers colluded to keep spreads artificially wide by avoiding odd-eighth quotes ($0.125). Cost investors billions.
stories.memorableDetail: After the scandal, the SEC mandated narrower spreads and eventually decimalization. Spreads shrank from $0.25 to pennies.
stories.usageNote: Why spread regulations and decimalization exist

8.title: Trade Processing & Settlement
8.coreNarrative: What happens after you click 'buy' is a complex dance of clearing, settling, and record-keeping.

stories.title: GameStop and the T+1 Push
stories.summary: Meme stock volatility caused brokers like Robinhood to halt trading because they couldn't meet settlement obligations. Accelerated the move to T+1.
stories.memorableDetail: Robinhood had to raise $3.4 billion in emergency capital in 48 hours. Congressional hearings followed. T+1 was implemented in 2024.
stories.usageNote: Why faster settlement matters

stories.title: The Paperwork Crisis
stories.summary: Trading volume overwhelmed manual processing. NYSE closed on Wednesdays to catch up. Led to creation of DTC for electronic settlement.
stories.memorableDetail: Firms literally couldn't process the paper. Stock certificates piled up in closets. Some firms failed just from back-office chaos.
stories.usageNote: Why electronic book-entry exists

stories.title: Lehman's Settlement Nightmare
stories.summary: Lehman's bankruptcy created unprecedented settlement failures. Trades in progress had no counterparty. Took years to unwind.
stories.memorableDetail: DTCC processed $500 billion in Lehman-related trades in the week after bankruptcy. The system held, barely.
stories.usageNote: Why central clearing and counterparty guarantees matter

stories.title: Stratton Oakmont's Pump and Dump
stories.summary: The 'Wolf of Wall Street' firm manipulated penny stocks, pumping prices with aggressive sales, then dumping. Defrauded investors of $200 million.
stories.memorableDetail: Jordan Belfort's boiler room had 1,000 brokers cold-calling from scripts. The firm was expelled by NASD in 1996.
stories.usageNote: Why manipulation rules exist
